clinical_study.brief_title: Iron Isomaltoside/Ferric Derisomaltose vs Iron Sucrose for Treatment of Iron Deficiency Anemia in Non-Dialysis-Dependent Chronic Kidney Disease
clinical_study.official_title: A Phase III, Randomised, Open-label, Comparative Safety and Efficacy Trial of Intravenous Iron Isomaltoside/Ferric Derisomaltose (Monofer®/Monoferric®) and Iron Sucrose in Subjects With Iron Deficiency Anaemia and Non-dialysis-dependent Chronic Kidney Disease (FERWON-NEPHRO)

brief_summary.textblock: Evaluation of safety and efficacy of iron isomaltoside/ferric derisomaltose compared with iron sucrose, in subjects with both non-dialysis-dependent chronic kidney disease (NDD-CKD) and iron deficiency anaemia (IDA).

detailed_description.textblock:
Iron deficiency anaemia (IDA) is a common problem associated with many chronic diseases such as chronic kidney disease (CKD). IDA can have a substantial medical and quality of life (QoL) burden on the subjects. Therapy of these subjects includes treating the underlying cause of IDA and restoring haemoglobin (Hb) concentration and iron stores.
This study evaluated the safety and efficacy of iron isomaltoside/ferric derisomaltose compared with iron sucrose in subjects with both non-dialysis-dependent chronic kidney disease (NDD-CKD) and iron deficiency anaemia (IDA).
The study subjects received either a single intravenous (IV) dose of iron isomaltoside/ferric derisomaltose (1000 mg at baseline) or iron sucrose (200 mg IV injections at baseline and repeated according to standard practice or physician choice up to a maximum of five times within the first two weeks starting at baseline; a cumulative dose of 1000 mg was recommended). The study subjects were monitored for up to 8 weeks from baseline.

primary_outcome.measure: Change in Hemoglobin (Hb) From Baseline to Week 8
primary_outcome.description: Efficacy Evaluate the effect of iron isomaltoside/ferric derisomaltose vs iron sucrose in subjects with non-dialysis-dependent chronic kidney disease (NDD-CKD) and iron deficiency anaemia (IDA). Response was defined as change from baseline in hemoglobin (Hb) to week 8, i.e. ability to increase Hb in subjects with NDD-CKD and IDA, when oral iron preparations were ineffective or could not be used, or in whom the Hb measurement at screening in Investigators' opinion were sufficiently low to require rapid repletion of iron stores.

primary_outcome.measure: Incidence of Protocol-defined Serious or Severe Hypersensitivity Reactions
primary_outcome.description: Safety For this endpoint, the number of participants with serious or severe hypersensitivity reactions were evaluated. The hypersensitivity reactions that were included in the analysis were those that started on or after the first dose of randomised treatment (i.e. treatment emergent). The terms used to define hypersensitivity were those specified by the Standardised MedDRA Queries (SMQ) for hypersensitivity, plus four additional terms: loss of consciousness, seizure, syncope, unresponsiveness. The potential hypersensitivity AEs were adjudicated in a blinded fashion by an independent Clinical Endpoint Adjudication Committee (CEAC). Results show only those participants that had adjudicated and confirmed serious or severe hypersensitivity reactions.

secondary_outcome.description: Safety Results show the composite cardiovascular AEs, that started on or after the first dose of randomised treatment (i.e. treatment emergent) up to week 8. The reported potential cardiovascular AEs were adjudicated in a blinded fashion by an independent Clinical Endpoint Adjudication Committee (CEAC). The potential cardiovascular AEs included the following: Death due to any cause Non-fatal myocardial infarction Non-fatal stroke Unstable angina requiring hospitalisation Congestive heart failure requiring hospitalisation or medical intervention Arrhythmias Hypertension Hypotension Results show only those participants that had adjudicated and confirmed treatment-emergent composite cardiovascular AEs.

secondary_outcome.measure: Time to First Composite Cardiovascular Safety AE
secondary_outcome.description: Safety Time to first composite cardiovascular AE was defined as the actual time in days from first dose of treatment until the date of the composite cardiovascular AE. For subjects not reporting a composite cardiovascular AE, the time was censored at the date of the last attended visit. Only the adjudicated and confirmed composite cardiovascular safety AEs, as judged by the CEAC, were considered for this endpoint. Time to first composite cardiovascular AE was defined as the actual time in days from first dose of treatment until the date of the composite cardiovascular AE. For subjects not reporting a composite cardiovascular AE, the time was censored at the date of the last attended visit.

secondary_outcome.measure: S-phosphate <2 mg/dL at Any Time From Baseline to Week 1, 2, 4, and 8
secondary_outcome.description: Safety Results show the number of participants who had s-phosphate <2 mg/dL at any time from baseline to week 1, 2, 4, or 8.

secondary_outcome.measure: Hb Concentration Increase of ≥1 g/dL From Baseline to Week 1, 2, 4, and 8
secondary_outcome.description: Efficacy Results show Hb responders to the treatment. A subject was considered a Hb responder to a certain week if an increase in Hb of at least 1 g/dL from baseline to the week in question was observed (from baseline to week 1, 2, 4, and 8).

secondary_outcome.measure: Time to Change in Hb Concentration ≥1 g/dL
secondary_outcome.description: Efficacy Time to change in Hb concentration ≥1 g/dL. Subjects who showed Hb concentration increase of ≥1 g/dL (from baseline to week 1, 2, 4, and 8). For responders, time to Hb response was defined as the scheduled time from baseline until the visit where the first Hb response was measured.

secondary_outcome.measure: Hb Concentration of >12 g/dL at Any Time From Week 1 to Week 8
secondary_outcome.description: Efficacy Hb concentration of >12 g/dL at any time from week 1 to week 8. Results show the number of participants who achieved Hb concentration of >12 g/dL at any time from week 1 to week 8.

secondary_outcome.measure: Hb Concentration Increase of ≥2 g/dL at Any Time From Week 1 to Week 8
secondary_outcome.description: Efficacy Results show the number of participants who achieved Hb concentration increase of ≥2 g/dL at any time from week 1 to week 8.

secondary_outcome.measure: S-Ferritin Concentration of ≥100 ng/mL and Transferrin Saturation (TSAT) of 20-50% at Any Time From Week 1 to Week 8
secondary_outcome.description: Efficacy Proportion of subjects reaching the composite endpoint of s-ferritin concentration ≥100 ng/mL and TSAT of 20-50% at any time from week 1 to 8.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in Hb Concentration From Baseline to Week 1, 2, and 4
secondary_outcome.description: Efficacy Change in Hb concentration from baseline to week 1, 2, and 4.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in S-ferritin From Baseline to Weeks 1, 2, 4, and 8
secondary_outcome.description: Efficacy Changes in s-ferritin from baseline to weeks 1, 2, 4, and 8.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in Transferrin Saturation (TSAT) From Baseline to Week 1, 2, 4, and 8
secondary_outcome.description: Efficacy Changes in transferrin saturation (TSAT) from baseline to week 1, 2, 4, and 8.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in Concentration of S-iron From Baseline to Week 1, 2, 4, and 8
secondary_outcome.description: Efficacy Changes in the concentrations of serum iron (s-iron) from baseline to week 1, 2, 4, and 8.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in Fatigue Symptoms From Baseline to Week 1, 2, and 8
secondary_outcome.description: Efficacy Change in fatigue symptoms from baseline to week 1, 2, and 8 was measured by the Functional Assessment of Chronic Illness Therapy (FACIT) Fatigue Scale. The Functional Assessment of Chronic Illness Therapy (FACIT) Fatigue Scale consisted of 13 items ranging from 0 (not at all) to 4 (very much), except items #7 and #8 which are reversed scored. The total score range is 0-52. A score of less than 30 indicated severe fatigue, and the higher the score, the better outcome/quality of life (QoL). If more than 50% of the items for a subject at a given visit were missing, the total score was not calculated. Total score was calculated as shown below: Total score= Sum of individual scores x 13 / Number of items answered

secondary_outcome.measure: Intervals in Screening for Diabetic Retinopathy (ISDR) Questionnaire
secondary_outcome.description: Pharmacoeconomics The Intervals in Screening for Diabetic Retinopathy (ISDR) questionnaire at the baseline visit assessed the resources used by subjects to receive treatment. Resources used on other trial activities were not included. ISDR responses were summarised using descriptive statistics. The data for this endpoint show the responses at baseline for both treatment groups. The frequency of drug administration between the 2 treatment groups is different, however, (i.e. up to a factor 5 in the iron sucrose treatment group).

secondary_outcome.measure: Intervals in Screening for Diabetic Retinopathy (ISDR) Questionnaire, Return Journey by Car
secondary_outcome.description: Pharmacoeconomics The Intervals in Screening for Diabetic Retinopathy (ISDR) questionnaire at the baseline visit assessed the resources used by subjects to receive treatment. Resources used on other trial activities were not included. ISDR responses were summarised using descriptive statistics. The data for this endpoint show the responses at baseline for both treatment groups. The frequency of drug administration between the 2 treatment groups is different, however, (i.e. up to a factor 5 in the iron sucrose treatment group).

Pharmacoeconomics Resources used by the health care staff (per administration), measured by the health care resource use questionnaire. The questionnaire assessed the time used by the health care staff during administration of the investigational product and the administration time (including the observational time). The health care participants included in the evaluation were: investigator, pharmacist, physician, study coordinator, study nurse. The data for this endpoint show the responses at baseline for both treatment groups. The frequency of drug administration between the 2 treatment groups is different (i.e. up to a factor 5 more frequent in the iron sucrose treatment group).

intervention.description: Iron isomaltoside/ferric derisomaltose (Monofer®/Monoferric®; 100 mg/mL) was the test product in this trial. The dose of iron isomaltoside/ferric derisomaltose for the individual subject was set to 1000 mg. The dose was diluted in 100 mL 0.9 % sodium chloride (100 mL bags) and administered as a single IV infusion over approximately 20 minutes.

Iron sucrose (Venofer®; 20 mg elemental iron/mL) was the comparator in this trial. Iron sucrose was administered as 200 mg undiluted IV injections over approximately 2-5 minutes and repeated according to standard practice or physician choice up to a maximum of five times within the first two weeks starting at baseline. A cumulative dose of 1000 mg was recommended.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria includes:
1. Men and women, ≥ 18 years
2. Hb ≤ 11 g/dL
3. Chronic renal impairment, as defined by either (i) eGFR < 60 mL/min/1.73m2 at screening (as calculated by modification of diet in renal disease (MDRD)), or (ii) Estimated Glomerular Filtration Rate (eGFR) < 90 mL/min/1.73m2 at screening and kidney damage as indicated by abnormalities in urine composition per medical history and/or intermediate/high risk of cardio-vascular disease based on the Framingham model
4. Screening s-ferritin ≤ 100 ng/mL, or ≤ 300 ng/mL if Transferrin Saturation (TSAT) ≤ 30 %
5. Either no Erythropoiesis Stimulating Agent (ESAs) or ESAs as a stable dose 4 weeks before randomisation
6. Willingness to participate and signing the informed consent form
Exclusion Criteria includes:
1. Anaemia predominantly caused by factors other than IDA
2. Hemochromatosis or other iron storage disorders
3. Previous serious hypersensitivity reactions to any IV iron compounds
4. Prior to screening or during the trial period; has or will be treated with a red blood cell transfusion, radiotherapy, and/or chemotherapy
5. Undergoing dialysis for treatment of CKD
6. Planned surgical procedure within the trial period
7. Decompensated liver cirrhosis or active hepatitis
8. Alcohol or drug abuse within the past 6 month.
9. Pregnant or nursing women.

overall_official.last_name: Pharmacosmos A/S Clinical and Non-clinical Research

link.description: The FERWON-NEPHRO trial; comparison of iron isomaltoside/ferric derisomaltose versus iron sucrose in NDD-CKD patients with iron deficiency anemia

results_reference.citation: Sunil Bhandari, Lars Lykke Thomsen. Single 1000 mg infusion of iron isomaltoside1000 single 1000 mg infusion of iron isomaltoside 1000 demonstrates a more rapid hemoglobin response and reduced risk of cardiovascular adverse events compared to multiple dose iron sucrose In patients with iron deficiency anemia and nondialysis-dependent CKD. Nephrology Dialysis Transplantation 34 (Supplement 1): i349-i350, 2019, https://academic.oup.com/ndt/article/34/Supplement_1/gfz101.SaO035/5515662

participant_flow.recruitment_details: A total of 2560 subjects were screened and 1538 subjects were randomised into the trial.

group.title: Iron Isomaltoside/Ferric Derisomaltose
group.description: Iron isomaltoside/ferric derisomaltose (Monofer®/Monoferric®; 100 mg/mL) was the test product in this trial. Subjects received iron isomaltoside/ferric derisomaltose (Monofer®/Monoferric®; 100 mg/mL) as a single IV infusion of 1000 mg at the baseline visit.

group.title: Iron Sucrose
group.description: Iron sucrose (Venofer®) was the comparator in this trial. Subjects received iron sucrose (Venofer®), 200 mg IV injection up to a maximum of 5 IV injections within the first 2 weeks, starting at baseline (a cumulative dose of 1000 mg was recommended).

outcome.title: Change in Hemoglobin (Hb) From Baseline to Week 8
outcome.description: Efficacy Evaluate the effect of iron isomaltoside/ferric derisomaltose vs iron sucrose in subjects with non-dialysis-dependent chronic kidney disease (NDD-CKD) and iron deficiency anaemia (IDA). Response was defined as change from baseline in hemoglobin (Hb) to week 8, i.e. ability to increase Hb in subjects with NDD-CKD and IDA, when oral iron preparations were ineffective or could not be used, or in whom the Hb measurement at screening in Investigators' opinion were sufficiently low to require rapid repletion of iron stores.
outcome.population: Intention to treat (ITT). All randomised subjects.

measure.title: Change in Hemoglobin (Hb) From Baseline to Week 8
measure.description: Efficacy Evaluate the effect of iron isomaltoside/ferric derisomaltose vs iron sucrose in subjects with non-dialysis-dependent chronic kidney disease (NDD-CKD) and iron deficiency anaemia (IDA). Response was defined as change from baseline in hemoglobin (Hb) to week 8, i.e. ability to increase Hb in subjects with NDD-CKD and IDA, when oral iron preparations were ineffective or could not be used, or in whom the Hb measurement at screening in Investigators' opinion were sufficiently low to require rapid repletion of iron stores.
measure.population: Intention to treat (ITT). All randomised subjects.

analysis.groups_desc: Power: With N=1000 subjects in the iron isomaltoside/ferric derisomaltose treatment group and with N=500 subjects in the iron sucrose treatment group, assuming no difference between the treatment groups and assuming a common standard deviation (SD) of 1.5 g/dL, the power was 100% for demonstrating non-inferiority of the change in Hb from baseline to week 8, using a non-inferiority margin of -0.5 g/dL. The significance level was set to 5%.
analysis.non_inferiority_desc: Non-inferiority could be claimed if the lower bound of the 95% confidence interval (CI) was above -0.5 g/dL.
analysis.estimate_desc: The Mixed Model for Repeated Measurement (MMRM) used for testing, included the fixed, categorical effects of treatment, week, treatment-by-week interaction, strata, and the continuous covariates of baseline Hb and baseline Hb-by-week interaction.

outcome.title: Incidence of Protocol-defined Serious or Severe Hypersensitivity Reactions
outcome.description: Safety For this endpoint, the number of participants with serious or severe hypersensitivity reactions were evaluated. The hypersensitivity reactions that were included in the analysis were those that started on or after the first dose of randomised treatment (i.e. treatment emergent). The terms used to define hypersensitivity were those specified by the Standardised MedDRA Queries (SMQ) for hypersensitivity, plus four additional terms: loss of consciousness, seizure, syncope, unresponsiveness. The potential hypersensitivity AEs were adjudicated in a blinded fashion by an independent Clinical Endpoint Adjudication Committee (CEAC). Results show only those participants that had adjudicated and confirmed serious or severe hypersensitivity reactions.
outcome.population: Safety analysis set. All randomised subjects who received at least one dose of the investigational product.

measure.title: Incidence of Protocol-defined Serious or Severe Hypersensitivity Reactions
measure.description: Safety For this endpoint, the number of participants with serious or severe hypersensitivity reactions were evaluated. The hypersensitivity reactions that were included in the analysis were those that started on or after the first dose of randomised treatment (i.e. treatment emergent). The terms used to define hypersensitivity were those specified by the Standardised MedDRA Queries (SMQ) for hypersensitivity, plus four additional terms: loss of consciousness, seizure, syncope, unresponsiveness. The potential hypersensitivity AEs were adjudicated in a blinded fashion by an independent Clinical Endpoint Adjudication Committee (CEAC). Results show only those participants that had adjudicated and confirmed serious or severe hypersensitivity reactions.
measure.population: Safety analysis set. All randomised subjects who received at least one dose of the investigational product.

analysis.groups_desc: Power: With N=1000 subjects in the iron isomaltoside/ferric derisomaltose, the power was 88% to demonstrate that the upper bound of the 95% CI of the incidence of treatment-emergent serious and/or severe non-serious hypersensitivity AEs was less than 3%. The significance level was set to 5%.

Risk difference between iron isomaltoside/ferric derisomaltose and iron sucrose was assessed for the individual trial with 95% Newcombe CI adjusted for stratum using the Cochran-Mantel-Haenszel method.

Risk difference between iron isomaltoside/ferric derisomaltose and iron sucrose was assessed for the pooled FERWON-IDA and FERWON-NEPHRO trials (2008 subjects treated with iron isomaltoside/ferric derisomaltose and 1000 subjects treated with iron sucrose) with 95% Newcombe CI adjusted for stratum using the Cochran-Mantel-Haenszel method.
analysis.non_inferiority_desc: Non-inferiority can be claimed if the upper bound of the 95% CI is below 1.5 % point.

outcome.title: Composite Cardiovascular Adverse Events (AEs)
outcome.description: Safety Results show the composite cardiovascular AEs, that started on or after the first dose of randomised treatment (i.e. treatment emergent) up to week 8. The reported potential cardiovascular AEs were adjudicated in a blinded fashion by an independent Clinical Endpoint Adjudication Committee (CEAC). The potential cardiovascular AEs included the following: Death due to any cause Non-fatal myocardial infarction Non-fatal stroke Unstable angina requiring hospitalisation Congestive heart failure requiring hospitalisation or medical intervention Arrhythmias Hypertension Hypotension Results show only those participants that had adjudicated and confirmed treatment-emergent composite cardiovascular AEs.
outcome.population: Safety analysis set. All randomised subjects who received at least one dose of the investigational product.

measure.title: Composite Cardiovascular Adverse Events (AEs)
measure.description: Safety Results show the composite cardiovascular AEs, that started on or after the first dose of randomised treatment (i.e. treatment emergent) up to week 8. The reported potential cardiovascular AEs were adjudicated in a blinded fashion by an independent Clinical Endpoint Adjudication Committee (CEAC). The potential cardiovascular AEs included the following: Death due to any cause Non-fatal myocardial infarction Non-fatal stroke Unstable angina requiring hospitalisation Congestive heart failure requiring hospitalisation or medical intervention Arrhythmias Hypertension Hypotension Results show only those participants that had adjudicated and confirmed treatment-emergent composite cardiovascular AEs.
measure.population: Safety analysis set. All randomised subjects who received at least one dose of the investigational product.

analysis.groups_desc: Adjudicated and confirmed treatment-emergent composite cardiovascular AEs. Any treatment emergent composite cardiovascular AEs were included in the statistical evaluation. The overall incidence of adjudicated and confirmed composite cardiovascular AEs was tabulated and compared between the treatment groups by a Fisher’s exact test.

outcome.title: Time to First Composite Cardiovascular Safety AE
outcome.description: Safety Time to first composite cardiovascular AE was defined as the actual time in days from first dose of treatment until the date of the composite cardiovascular AE. For subjects not reporting a composite cardiovascular AE, the time was censored at the date of the last attended visit. Only the adjudicated and confirmed composite cardiovascular safety AEs, as judged by the CEAC, were considered for this endpoint. Time to first composite cardiovascular AE was defined as the actual time in days from first dose of treatment until the date of the composite cardiovascular AE. For subjects not reporting a composite cardiovascular AE, the time was censored at the date of the last attended visit.
outcome.population: Safety analysis set. All randomised subjects who received at least one dose of the investigational product.

measure.title: Time to First Composite Cardiovascular Safety AE
measure.description: Safety Time to first composite cardiovascular AE was defined as the actual time in days from first dose of treatment until the date of the composite cardiovascular AE. For subjects not reporting a composite cardiovascular AE, the time was censored at the date of the last attended visit. Only the adjudicated and confirmed composite cardiovascular safety AEs, as judged by the CEAC, were considered for this endpoint. Time to first composite cardiovascular AE was defined as the actual time in days from first dose of treatment until the date of the composite cardiovascular AE. For subjects not reporting a composite cardiovascular AE, the time was censored at the date of the last attended visit.
measure.population: Safety analysis set. All randomised subjects who received at least one dose of the investigational product.

measurement_list.measurement: The number of adjudicated and confirmed composite cardiovascular safety AEs was too low (N=42) for estimation of median and 95% CI.
The number of adjudicated and confirmed composite cardiovascular safety AEs was too low (N=35) for estimation of median and 95% CI.

analysis.groups_desc: The time to first adjudicated and confirmed composite cardiovascular AEs was estimated using the Kaplan-Meier method and the hypothesis of no treatment difference was assessed by a log-rank test.

outcome.title: S-phosphate <2 mg/dL at Any Time From Baseline to Week 1, 2, 4, and 8
outcome.description: Safety Results show the number of participants who had s-phosphate <2 mg/dL at any time from baseline to week 1, 2, 4, or 8.
outcome.population: Safety analysis set. All randomised subjects who received at least one dose of the investigational product.

measure.title: S-phosphate <2 mg/dL at Any Time From Baseline to Week 1, 2, 4, and 8
measure.description: Safety Results show the number of participants who had s-phosphate <2 mg/dL at any time from baseline to week 1, 2, 4, or 8.
measure.population: Safety analysis set. All randomised subjects who received at least one dose of the investigational product.

outcome.title: Hb Concentration Increase of ≥1 g/dL From Baseline to Week 1, 2, 4, and 8
outcome.description: Efficacy Results show Hb responders to the treatment. A subject was considered a Hb responder to a certain week if an increase in Hb of at least 1 g/dL from baseline to the week in question was observed (from baseline to week 1, 2, 4, and 8).

measure.title: Hb Concentration Increase of ≥1 g/dL From Baseline to Week 1, 2, 4, and 8
measure.description: Efficacy Results show Hb responders to the treatment. A subject was considered a Hb responder to a certain week if an increase in Hb of at least 1 g/dL from baseline to the week in question was observed (from baseline to week 1, 2, 4, and 8).

analysis.groups_desc: Week 1 Hb increase of ≥1 g/dL from baseline to week 1. Proportion of Hb responders to each week was analysed using a repeated measures logistic regression model with treatment, visit, strata, and treatment by visit interaction as fixed effects and baseline value as covariate.

Week 2 Hb increase of ≥1 g/dL from baseline to week 2. Proportion of Hb responders to each week was analysed using a repeated measures logistic regression model with treatment, visit, strata, and treatment by visit interaction as fixed effects and baseline value as covariate.

Week 4 Hb increase of ≥1 g/dL from baseline to week 4. Proportion of Hb responders to each week was analysed using a repeated measures logistic regression model with treatment, visit, strata, and treatment by visit interaction as fixed effects and baseline value as covariate.

Week 8 Hb increase of ≥1 g/dL from baseline to week 8. Proportion of Hb responders to each week was analysed using a repeated measures logistic regression model with treatment, visit, strata, and treatment by visit interaction as fixed effects and baseline value as covariate.

outcome.title: Time to Change in Hb Concentration ≥1 g/dL
outcome.description: Efficacy Time to change in Hb concentration ≥1 g/dL. Subjects who showed Hb concentration increase of ≥1 g/dL (from baseline to week 1, 2, 4, and 8). For responders, time to Hb response was defined as the scheduled time from baseline until the visit where the first Hb response was measured.

measure.title: Time to Change in Hb Concentration ≥1 g/dL
measure.description: Efficacy Time to change in Hb concentration ≥1 g/dL. Subjects who showed Hb concentration increase of ≥1 g/dL (from baseline to week 1, 2, 4, and 8). For responders, time to Hb response was defined as the scheduled time from baseline until the visit where the first Hb response was measured.

measurement_list.measurement: The 95% Confidence Interval value for this treatment group could not be calculated.

analysis.groups_desc: Time to Hb response was estimated using the Kaplan-Meier method and the hypothesis of no treatment difference was assessed by a 2-sided log-rank test.

outcome.title: Hb Concentration of >12 g/dL at Any Time From Week 1 to Week 8
outcome.description: Efficacy Hb concentration of >12 g/dL at any time from week 1 to week 8. Results show the number of participants who achieved Hb concentration of >12 g/dL at any time from week 1 to week 8.

measure.title: Hb Concentration of >12 g/dL at Any Time From Week 1 to Week 8
measure.description: Efficacy Hb concentration of >12 g/dL at any time from week 1 to week 8. Results show the number of participants who achieved Hb concentration of >12 g/dL at any time from week 1 to week 8.

analysis.groups_desc: The proportion of subjects who achieved a Hb level of >12 g/dL at any time from week 1 to week 8 was analysed using a logistic regression model with treatment and strata as fixed effects. The estimated treatment ratio of iron isomaltoside/ferric derisomaltose versus iron sucrose is presented with 95% CI and corresponding p-value.

outcome.title: Hb Concentration Increase of ≥2 g/dL at Any Time From Week 1 to Week 8
outcome.description: Efficacy Results show the number of participants who achieved Hb concentration increase of ≥2 g/dL at any time from week 1 to week 8.

measure.title: Hb Concentration Increase of ≥2 g/dL at Any Time From Week 1 to Week 8
measure.description: Efficacy Results show the number of participants who achieved Hb concentration increase of ≥2 g/dL at any time from week 1 to week 8.

analysis.groups_desc: The proportion of subjects who achieved an increase in Hb concentration ≥2 g/dL at any time from week 1 to week 8 was analysed using a logistic regression model with treatment and strata as fixed effects. The estimated treatment ratio of iron isomaltoside/ferric derisomaltose versus iron sucrose was presented with 95% CI and corresponding p-value.

outcome.title: S-Ferritin Concentration of ≥100 ng/mL and Transferrin Saturation (TSAT) of 20-50% at Any Time From Week 1 to Week 8
outcome.description: Efficacy Proportion of subjects reaching the composite endpoint of s-ferritin concentration ≥100 ng/mL and TSAT of 20-50% at any time from week 1 to 8.

measure.title: S-Ferritin Concentration of ≥100 ng/mL and Transferrin Saturation (TSAT) of 20-50% at Any Time From Week 1 to Week 8
measure.description: Efficacy Proportion of subjects reaching the composite endpoint of s-ferritin concentration ≥100 ng/mL and TSAT of 20-50% at any time from week 1 to 8.

analysis.groups_desc: Proportion of subject who achieved a s-ferritin level of ≥100 ng/mL AND a TSAT of 20-50% at any time from week 1 to week 8 was analysed using a logistic regression model with treatment and strata as fixed effects. The estimated treatment ratio of iron isomaltoside/ferric derisomaltose versus iron sucrose is presented with 95% CI and corresponding p-value.

outcome.title: Change in Hb Concentration From Baseline to Week 1, 2, and 4
outcome.description: Efficacy Change in Hb concentration from baseline to week 1, 2, and 4.

measure.title: Change in Hb Concentration From Baseline to Week 1, 2, and 4
measure.description: Efficacy Change in Hb concentration from baseline to week 1, 2, and 4.

analysis.groups_desc: Week 1 Change in Hb concentration from baseline to week 1 was analysed using a MMRM including treatment, week, treatment-by-week interaction, and strata as factors and baseline value and baseline value-by-week interaction as covariates.

Week 2 Change in Hb concentration from baseline to week 2 was analysed using a MMRM including treatment, week, treatment-by-week interaction, and strata as factors and baseline value and baseline value-by-week interaction as covariates.

Week 4 Change in Hb concentration from baseline to week 4 was analysed using a MMRM including treatment, week, treatment-by-week interaction, and strata as factors and baseline value and baseline value-by-week interaction as covariates.

outcome.title: Change in S-ferritin From Baseline to Weeks 1, 2, 4, and 8
outcome.description: Efficacy Changes in s-ferritin from baseline to weeks 1, 2, 4, and 8.

measure.title: Change in S-ferritin From Baseline to Weeks 1, 2, 4, and 8
measure.description: Efficacy Changes in s-ferritin from baseline to weeks 1, 2, 4, and 8.

analysis.groups_desc: Week 1 Change in concentrations of s-ferritin from baseline to week 1 was analysed using a MMRM including treatment, week, treatment-by-week interaction, and strata as factors and baseline value and baseline value-by-week interaction as covariates. The estimated treatment differences based on the least square means of the treatment by-week interaction effects are presented by week, include 95% CIs and corresponding p-value.

Week 2 Change in concentrations of s-ferritin from baseline to week 2 was analysed using MMRM including treatment, week, treatment-by-week interaction, and strata as factors and baseline value and baseline value-by-week interaction as covariates. The estimated treatment differences based on the least square means of the treatment by-week interaction effects are presented by week, include 95% CIs and corresponding p-value.

Week 4 Change in concentrations of s-ferritin from baseline to week 4 was analysed using MMRM including treatment, week, treatment-by-week interaction, and strata as factors and baseline value and baseline value-by-week interaction as covariates. The estimated treatment differences based on the least square means of the treatment by-week interaction effects are presented by week, include 95% CIs and corresponding p-value.

Week 8 Change in concentrations of s-ferritin from baseline to week 8 was analysed using MMRM including treatment, week, treatment-by-week interaction, and strata as factors and baseline value and baseline value-by-week interaction as covariates. The estimated treatment differences based on the least square means of the treatment by-week interaction effects are presented by week, include 95% CIs and corresponding p-value.

outcome.title: Change in Transferrin Saturation (TSAT) From Baseline to Week 1, 2, 4, and 8
outcome.description: Efficacy Changes in transferrin saturation (TSAT) from baseline to week 1, 2, 4, and 8.

measure.title: Change in Transferrin Saturation (TSAT) From Baseline to Week 1, 2, 4, and 8
measure.description: Efficacy Changes in transferrin saturation (TSAT) from baseline to week 1, 2, 4, and 8.

analysis.groups_desc: Week 1 Change in TSAT from baseline to week 1 was analysed using MMRM including treatment, week, treatment-by-week interaction, and strata as factors and baseline value and baseline value-by-week interaction as covariates. The estimated treatment differences based on the least square means of the treatment by-week interaction effects are presented by week, include 95% CIs and corresponding p-value.

Week 2 Change in TSAT from baseline to week 2 was analysed using MMRM including treatment, week, treatment-by-week interaction, and strata as factors and baseline value and baseline value-by-week interaction as covariates. The estimated treatment differences based on the least square means of the treatment by-week interaction effects are presented by week, include 95% CIs and corresponding p-value.

Week 4 Change in TSAT from baseline to week 4 was analysed using MMRM including treatment, week, treatment-by-week interaction, and strata as factors and baseline value and baseline value-by-week interaction as covariates. The estimated treatment differences based on the least square means of the treatment by-week interaction effects are presented by week, include 95% CIs and corresponding p-value.

Week 8 Change in TSAT from baseline to week 8 was analysed using MMRM including treatment, week, treatment-by-week interaction, and strata as factors and baseline value and baseline value-by-week interaction as covariates. The estimated treatment differences based on the least square means of the treatment by-week interaction effects are presented by week, include 95% CIs and corresponding p-value.

outcome.description: Efficacy Changes in the concentrations of serum iron (s-iron) from baseline to week 1, 2, 4, and 8.

measure.title: Change in Concentration of S-iron From Baseline to Week 1, 2, 4, and 8
measure.description: Efficacy Changes in the concentrations of serum iron (s-iron) from baseline to week 1, 2, 4, and 8.

analysis.groups_desc: Week 1 Change in s-iron from baseline to week 1 was analysed using a Mixed Model for Repeated Measurement (MMRM) including treatment, week, treatment-by-week interaction, and strata as factors and baseline value and baseline value-by-week interaction as covariates. The estimated treatment differences based on the least square means of the treatment-by week interaction effects are presented by week, including 95% CIs and corresponding p-value.

Week 2 Change in s-iron from baseline to week 2 was analysed using a Mixed Model for Repeated Measurement (MMRM) including treatment, week, treatment-by-week interaction, and strata as factors and baseline value and baseline value-by-week interaction as covariates. The estimated treatment differences based on the least square means of the treatment-by week interaction effects are presented by week, including 95% CIs and corresponding p-value.

Week 4 Change in s-iron from baseline to week 4 was analysed using a Mixed Model for Repeated Measurement (MMRM) including treatment, week, treatment-by-week interaction, and strata as factors and baseline value and baseline value-by-week interaction as covariates. The estimated treatment differences based on the least square means of the treatment-by week interaction effects are presented by week, including 95% CIs and corresponding p-value.

Week 8 Change in s-iron from baseline to week 8 was analysed using a Mixed Model for Repeated Measurement (MMRM) including treatment, week, treatment-by-week interaction, and strata as factors and baseline value and baseline value-by-week interaction as covariates. The estimated treatment differences based on the least square means of the treatment-by week interaction effects are presented by week, including 95% CIs and corresponding p-value.

outcome.title: Change in Fatigue Symptoms From Baseline to Week 1, 2, and 8
outcome.description: Efficacy Change in fatigue symptoms from baseline to week 1, 2, and 8 was measured by the Functional Assessment of Chronic Illness Therapy (FACIT) Fatigue Scale. The Functional Assessment of Chronic Illness Therapy (FACIT) Fatigue Scale consisted of 13 items ranging from 0 (not at all) to 4 (very much), except items #7 and #8 which are reversed scored. The total score range is 0-52. A score of less than 30 indicated severe fatigue, and the higher the score, the better outcome/quality of life (QoL). If more than 50% of the items for a subject at a given visit were missing, the total score was not calculated. Total score was calculated as shown below: Total score= Sum of individual scores x 13 / Number of items answered

measure.title: Change in Fatigue Symptoms From Baseline to Week 1, 2, and 8
measure.description: Efficacy Change in fatigue symptoms from baseline to week 1, 2, and 8 was measured by the Functional Assessment of Chronic Illness Therapy (FACIT) Fatigue Scale. The Functional Assessment of Chronic Illness Therapy (FACIT) Fatigue Scale consisted of 13 items ranging from 0 (not at all) to 4 (very much), except items #7 and #8 which are reversed scored. The total score range is 0-52. A score of less than 30 indicated severe fatigue, and the higher the score, the better outcome/quality of life (QoL). If more than 50% of the items for a subject at a given visit were missing, the total score was not calculated. Total score was calculated as shown below: Total score= Sum of individual scores x 13 / Number of items answered

analysis.groups_desc: Week 1 Change in fatigue symptoms score from baseline to week 1 was analysed using MMRM including treatment, week, treatment-by-week interaction, and strata as factors and baseline score and baseline score-by-week interaction as covariates.

Week 2 Change in fatigue symptoms score from baseline to week 2 was analysed using MMRM including treatment, week, treatment-by-week interaction, and strata as factors and baseline score and baseline score-by-week interaction as covariates.

Week 8 Change in fatigue symptoms score from baseline to week 8 was analysed using MMRM including treatment, week, treatment-by-week interaction, and strata as factors and baseline score and baseline score-by-week interaction as covariates.

outcome.title: Intervals in Screening for Diabetic Retinopathy (ISDR) Questionnaire
outcome.description: Pharmacoeconomics The Intervals in Screening for Diabetic Retinopathy (ISDR) questionnaire at the baseline visit assessed the resources used by subjects to receive treatment. Resources used on other trial activities were not included. ISDR responses were summarised using descriptive statistics. The data for this endpoint show the responses at baseline for both treatment groups. The frequency of drug administration between the 2 treatment groups is different, however, (i.e. up to a factor 5 in the iron sucrose treatment group).

class.title: Took time off work to attend, YES
Assistance by others to attend visit, YES
Others took time off work to attend, YES

outcome.title: Health Care Resource Use Questionnaire
outcome.description: Pharmacoeconomics Resources used by the health care staff (per administration), measured by the health care resource use questionnaire. The questionnaire assessed the time used by the health care staff during administration of the investigational product and the administration time (including the observational time). The health care participants included in the evaluation were: investigator, pharmacist, physician, study coordinator, study nurse. The data for this endpoint show the responses at baseline for both treatment groups. The frequency of drug administration between the 2 treatment groups is different (i.e. up to a factor 5 more frequent in the iron sucrose treatment group).

group.title: Iron Isomaltoside/Ferric Derisomaltose
group.description: Health care staff involved in the iron isomaltoside/ferric derisomaltose treatment group. Assessment of the time used by the health care staff during administration of the investigational product and the administration time (including the observational time).

group.title: Iron Sucrose
group.description: Health care staff involved in the iron sucrose treatment group. Assessment of the time used by the health care staff during administration of the investigational product and the administration time (including the observational time).

measure.title: Health Care Resource Use Questionnaire
measure.description: Pharmacoeconomics Resources used by the health care staff (per administration), measured by the health care resource use questionnaire. The questionnaire assessed the time used by the health care staff during administration of the investigational product and the administration time (including the observational time). The health care participants included in the evaluation were: investigator, pharmacist, physician, study coordinator, study nurse. The data for this endpoint show the responses at baseline for both treatment groups. The frequency of drug administration between the 2 treatment groups is different (i.e. up to a factor 5 more frequent in the iron sucrose treatment group).

reported_events.time_frame: From the time a subjects had signed the informed consent form (CRF) and until they had completed the study, all adverse events (AEs) or serious adverse events (SAEs) were reported in the CRF. The actual study duration was 8 weeks (or shorted if the trial was discontinued). Overall, eligible subjects participated in the trial for approximately 10 weeks (including a 14-day screening period).
reported_events.desc: An AE was described as follows: the nature of the event was described in precise, standard medical terminology (i.e. not necessarily the exact words used by the subject). If known, a specific diagnosis was stated. Furthermore, the Investigator described an AE regarding seriousness, severity, relatedness, and outcome.

category.title: Neoplasms benign, malignant and unspecified (incl cysts and polyps)

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: Institution may publish the study results. Before submission for publication or presentation, Institution shall allow Sponsor not less than 90 days to review any manuscript and not less than 30 days to review any poster presentation, abstract, or any other written or oral material which describes or discloses the study results. If sponsor so requests in writing, Institution shall withhold any publication or presentation for an additional 90 days.
